subNodes.conversationText: root

A small being was sitting in the tall grass outside the witches' house. She looked like a redcap but had a gentle countenance. A sack as big as she was sat on the ground beside her. She had her knees tucked up to her body and was resting her chin on them. When she saw <FirstName>, she waved.
[Continue.]
"Greetings. I thought you might come this way."
"Who are you?"
The creature laughed gaily. "Look!"
[Continue.]
She reached into the sack at her feet. When she took her hands out, she was cupping a mound of dazzling, rich jewels -- carbuncles, diamonds, sapphires -- between them.
"You did? Why?"
"Isn't this where you're staying?" The young witch couldn't deny this.
[Continue.]
She reached into the sack at her feet. When she took her hands out, she was cupping a mound of dazzling, rich jewels -- carbuncles, diamonds, sapphires -- between them.
[Continue.]
"My name is Sieben. I create things from dross."
"Ah. A drossmaker. Now I understand why you haven't attacked me."
"Yes. My only craft is craft."
"What do you make?"

"Coins that crumble like cakes, gems that wither like flowers, and other baubles." She tossed the small hoard into the air. The carbuncles turned into orange pebbles, the diamonds into dandelion seeds, and the sapphires into rainwater.
"Would you trade fairly with a mortal?"
Sieben went on to describe in detail the items she could make from dross and their many wondrous properties.
[End.]
[End.]
[End.]
[End.]
[End.]
[End.]
"Interesting. Would you use your craft to help me?"
"Dross?"

"The residue of my kin. I use it. I know that sounds morbid to you, but we're not flesh, not in the same way you are. Your battles have already loaded you down with moth-dross. You can't see or feel it, but it's there."
[Continue.]
"I can make many things from it."
[Continue.]

"Coins that crumble like cakes, gems that wither like flowers, and other baubles." She tossed the small hoard into the air. The carbuncles turned into orange pebbles, the diamonds into dandelion seeds, and the sapphires into rainwater.
"Interesting. Would you use your craft to help me?"
"Yes. I can make many things."
[Continue.]

"Coins that crumble like cakes, gems that wither like flowers, and other baubles." She tossed the small hoard into the air. The carbuncles turned into orange pebbles, the diamonds into dandelion seeds, and the sapphires into rainwater.
[Continue.]
"I'm Sieben. You are <FirstName>, the young witch, the covenless one."
"You know a lot about me."
"I do. We do."
"We? You mean the Congress of Moths?"
"Yes. My siblings."
[Continue.]
"Still, I don't want to fight you. We can benefit each other. I'm a drossmaker."
"A drossmaker? What's that?"
"Do the witches know you're in their yard?"

"I'm not sure. I've seen Eldest Lady's cat coming and going -- he might have told her. But I make sure to hide myself from her. I don't fear her, and I'm sure she wouldn't fear me, but circumstances are such that a meeting between us isn't desirable. We are not on good terms with her."
[Continue.]
"But let me you tell why I've been waiting for you. Like I said, I work with dross."
[Continue.]

"Dross is what the Congress of Moths is made of. It's invisible on its own, but the dust of your world gives it form.

"In ancient times, the moths made a bargain with us. We would decorate their wings, and they would let us borrow their dust when we came here. A bad bargain! We have borrowed too much, rioted, and overstayed our welcome."
"Who do you mean?"
"The Congress of Moths, of course. I am not human, as you can see."
[Continue.]
"Still, I don't want to fight you. We can benefit each other. I'm a drossmaker."
"Do the witches know you're in their yard?"

"I'm not sure. I've seen Eldest Lady's cat coming and going -- he might have told her. But I make sure to hide myself from her. I don't fear her, and I'm sure she wouldn't fear me, but circumstances are such that a meeting between us isn't desirable. We are not on good terms with her."
"We? You mean the Congress of Moths?"
"Who do you mean?"
"A drossmaker? What's that?"

"Dross is what the Congress of Moths is made of. It's invisible on its own, but the dust of your world gives it form.

"In ancient times, the moths made a bargain with us. We would decorate their wings, and they would let us borrow their dust when we came here. A bad bargain! We have borrowed too much, rioted, and overstayed our welcome."
[Continue.]

She shrugged. "But that's the way we are. In any case, whenever you destroy one of us, the dross doesn't have anywhere to go, so it sticks to you, the nearest and most potent source of desire and imagination -- two things it has much in common with. I can take it from you and mold it into lovely, useful objects. Look!"
[Continue.]

She reached into the sack at her feet. When she took her hands out, she was cupping a mound of dazzling, rich jewels -- carbuncles, diamonds, and sapphires.

Then she tossed the small hoard into the air. The carbuncles turned into orange pebbles, the diamonds into dandelion seeds, and the sapphires into rainwater.
"Your creations don't last very long."

"Is that a bad thing? Nothing lasts long. Nothing lasts." Then she laughed. "I forget how different we are. We don't like stillness or the idea of permanence. You value these things, despite the universe's insistence that valuing them is a bad idea... But don't worry. What I make will last long enough to help you."
[Continue.]
"Impressive work."
The otherworldly artisan nodded in gratitude.
[Continue.]
Sieben went on to describe in detail the items she could make from dross and their many wondrous properties.
"Hello again. Do you want me to make something for you?"
"Yes."
Sieben described her inventory to the young witch.
[End.]
[End.]
[End.]
[End.]
[End.]
[End.]
"I was hoping we could talk instead."
"Talk?"
"Why is the Congress of Moths here?"
"I cannot say. We may seem lawless to you, but strange laws bind us."
[Continue.]
"One of these laws means I must hold my tongue with you. We are here for a reason -- but even I am unsure what that reason is."
"I see. May I ask something else?"
"No. I've probably said too much. Don't ask me more questions."
"Very well. Let me see your goods."
Sieben described her inventory to the young witch.
"Very well. Goodbye."
"Very well. Let me see your goods."
Sieben described her inventory to the young witch.
"What can you tell me about the witches?"
"Eldest Lady and Middle One? You know them better than I do."
"I see. May I ask something else?"
"Very well. Let me see your goods."
"Why are you helping me at all?"
"I cannot say. We may seem lawless to you, but strange laws bind us."
[Continue.]
"One of these laws means I must hold my tongue with you. I am helping you for a reason -- but even I am unsure what that reason is."
"I see. May I ask something else?"
"Very well. Let me see your goods."
"Never mind."
"No, not right now."
